title: What is the device used to connect multiple signals from both voice and data and put them on the same WAN? - Quora

response.answer_text: To add to Rick Noonan’s great answer… Modern WANs are packetised, and use various link-layer protocols (Ethernet, etc) to transmit data. Voice is packet switched (eg SIP), compared to circuit switched (eg ISDN) in the past. This means voice is just another packet, no different to web browsing, etc. Hence it travels across the same WAN. In the past, voice would often use a separate WAN link, an ISDN2 or ISDN30 link to your voice service provider.

What you describe is a Router. Routers were invented for this purpose, bring different information, from different networks, together onto a common set of connected networks. Some LAN switches contain routing functions, and some routers contain LAN switching functions, so the definitions can become blurry sometimes. WAN’s or Wide Area Networks, are typically connected by routers, or sometimes switches that contain routing functions/features.

The correct answer is BroadBand Modems... and its even in the name. Broad means many or multiple... Base means one or single. WAN is a Broadband Connection: DSL, Fiber, Wireless, Cable modem. LAN is a Baseband Connection: Ethernet.
